blank3_info_sec2 = [[File:GCRTA wordmark logo.svg|30px|link=RTA Rapid Transit]] }} '''Cleveland''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|l|iː|v|l|ə|n|d}} {{respell|KLEEV|lənd}}) is a city in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Ohio]], and the [[county seat]] of [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]].{{cite web |url=http://www.naco.org/Counties/Pages/FindACounty.aspx |accessdate=June 7, 2011 |title=Find a County |publisher=National Association of Counties |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531210815/http://www.naco.org/Counties/Pages/FindACounty.aspx |archivedate=May 31, 2011 |df=mdy }} The city proper has a population of 385,525, making it the [[List of United States cities by population|52nd-largest city]] in the [[United States]] and the [[List of cities in Ohio|second-largest city]] in Ohio. [[Greater Cleveland]] is ranked as the [[List of Metropolitan Statistical Areas|33rd-largest metropolitan area]] in the U.S., with 2,057,009 people in 2018.{{cite web|url=https://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/PEP/2018/PEPANNRES/0100000US.31000|title=Annual Estimates of the Resident Population: April 1, 2010 to July 1, 2018 |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]], Population Division |date=April 2019 |accessdate=May 30, 2019}} A [[Globalization and World Cities Research Network|Gamma +]] city, Cleveland anchors the [[Northeast Ohio|Cleveland–Akron–Canton Combined Statistical Area]], which had a population of 3,515,646 in 2010 and is ranked 15th in the United States. The city is located on the southern shore of [[Lake Erie]], across the U.S. [[Canada–United States border|maritime border]] with [[Canada]] and approximately {{convert|60|mi|km|sigfig=1|abbr=off|sp=us}} west of the Ohio-[[Pennsylvania]] state border. It was founded in 1796 near the mouth of the [[Cuyahoga River]] by General [[Moses Cleaveland]]. It became a manufacturing center due to its location on both the river and the lake shore, as well as being connected to numerous [[canal]]s and [[Rail transport in the United States|railroad]] lines. [[Economy of Greater Cleveland|Cleveland's economy]] relies on diversified sectors such as manufacturing, financial services, [[Health care in the United States|healthcare]], biomedicals, and higher education, and it the 31st in the nation per economic output, with GDP of $134 billion in 2018.{{cite web |url=https://apps.bea.gov/itable/drilldown.cfm?reqid=70&stepnum=40&Major_Area=5&State=5&Area=XX&TableId=501&Statistic=1&Year=2018&YearBegin=-1&Year_End=-1&Unit_Of_Measure=Levels&Rank=1&Drill=1&nRange=5 |title=Regional Economic Accounts GDP and Personal Income |website=apps.bea.gov |accessdate=26 February 2020}} The city's major cultural institutions include the [[Cleveland Museum of Art]], the [[Cleveland Orchestra]], [[Playhouse Square]], and the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]. Known as "[[The Forest City]]" among many other [[List of nicknames for Cleveland|nicknames]], Cleveland serves as the center of the [[Cleveland Metroparks]] [[nature reserve]] system.{{cite web|url=http://ech.case.edu/cgi/article.pl?id=FC3|title=Forest City|year=1997|encyclopedia=The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History|publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]]|accessdate=July 10, 2016}} ==History== {{Main|History of Cleveland}} {{see also|Timeline of Cleveland history}} [[File:Gen. Moses Cleaveland by James G. C. Hamilton - DSC07989.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.03|[[James G. C. Hamilton]]'s 1888 statue of Gen. [[Moses Cleaveland]].]] ===Establishment=== Cleveland was established on July 22, 1796 by surveyors of the [[Connecticut Land Company]] when they laid out [[Connecticut]]'s [[Connecticut Western Reserve|Western Reserve]] into townships and a capital city. They named the new settlement "Cleaveland" after their leader, General [[Moses Cleaveland]].{{cite web | url=https://case.edu/ech/articles/c/cleaveland-moses | title=Cleaveland, Moses |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate=August 21, 2019| date=January 20, 2019 }} Cleaveland oversaw the [[New England]]-style design of the plan for what would become the modern downtown area, centered on [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]], before returning home, never again to visit Ohio. The first permanent settler in Cleaveland was [[Lorenzo Carter]], who built a cabin on the banks of the Cuyahoga River.{{cite web | title =Lorenzo Carter Cabin | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/286 | accessdate =August 21, 2019}} The Village of Cleaveland was incorporated on December 23, 1814.{{cite web | url=http://ech.case.edu/timeline.html | title=Cleveland: A Bicentennial Timeline |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]]|accessdate=August 5, 2019| date=May 31, 2019 }} In spite of the nearby swampy lowlands and harsh winters, the town's waterfront location proved to be an advantage, giving it access to Great Lakes trade. It grew rapidly after the 1832 completion of the [[Ohio and Erie Canal]]. This key link between the [[Ohio River]] and the [[Great Lakes]] connected it to the Atlantic Ocean via the [[Erie Canal]] and Hudson River, and later via the [[St. Lawrence Seaway]]. Its products could reach markets on the [[Gulf of Mexico]] via the [[Mississippi River]]. The town's growth continued with added railroad links.{{cite web | url=https://case.edu/ech/articles/o/ohio-and-erie-canal | title=Ohio and Erie Canal |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate=August 5, 2019| date=February 7, 2019 }} In 1831, the spelling of the town's name was altered by ''The Cleveland Advertiser'' newspaper. In order to fit the name on the newspaper's [[Nameplate (publishing)|masthead]], the editors dropped the first "a", reducing the city's name to ''Cleveland'', which eventually became the official spelling.{{cite journal|last1=Bourne|first1=Henry E.|title=The Story of Cleveland|journal=New England Magazine|date=1896|volume=14|issue=6|page=744|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-Og7AQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Cleveland%20Advertiser%22%201831%20spelling&pg=PA744#v=onepage&q&f=false|quote=It was agreeable to the wishes of many of our oldest and most intelligent citizens, who are of the opinion that the 'a' is superfluous.}} In 1836, Cleveland was officially incorporated as a city. That same year, Cleveland, then only on the eastern banks of the Cuyahoga River, nearly erupted into open warfare with neighboring [[Ohio City (Cuyahoga County), Ohio|Ohio City]] over a bridge connecting the two communities.{{cite web | url=https://case.edu/ech/articles/c/columbus-street-bridge | title=Columbus Street Bridge | encyclopedia=The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History|publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]] | accessdate=July 15, 2019}} Ohio City remained an independent municipality until its [[Municipal annexation in the United States|annexation]] by Cleveland in 1854. ===Growth and expansion=== [[File:Cleveland 1877.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|[[Bird's-eye view]] of Cleveland in 1877.]] Cleveland witnessed rapid growth after the [[Cleveland in the American Civil War|American Civil War]]. The city's prime geographic location as a transportation hub between the East Coast and the Midwest played an important role in its development as a commercial center. Cleveland served as a destination for iron ore shipped from [[Minnesota]], along with coal transported by rail. In 1870, [[John D. Rockefeller]] founded [[Standard Oil]] in Cleveland. In 1885, he moved its headquarters to [[New York City]], which had become a center of finance and business.{{cite web | url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/rockefellers/timeline/index.html | title=Rockefellers Timeline | accessdate=July 7, 2010 | date=1999–2000 | publisher=PBS | quote=1870 Rockefeller founds Standard Oil of Ohio with $1 million in capital, the largest corporation in the country. The new company controls 10% of U.S. petroleum refining. 1885 Standard Oil Standard Oil moves into new headquarters at 26 Broadway in New York.}} By the early 20th century, Cleveland had emerged as a major American manufacturing center. Its businesses included automotive companies such as [[Peerless]], People's, [[Jordan Motor Car Company|Jordan]], [[Chandler Motor Car|Chandler]], and [[Winton Motor Carriage Company|Winton]], maker of the first car driven across the U.S. Other manufacturers in Cleveland produced [[steam car|steam-powered]] cars, which included [[White Motor Company|White]] and [[Gaeth]], as well as the [[electric car]] company [[Baker Motor Vehicle|Baker]].Clymer, Floyd. ''Treasury of Early American Automobiles, 1877–1925'' (New York: Bonanza Books, 1950), pp. 178, 156. [[File:Johnson photo P&P.jpg|thumb|upright=1|left|[[Herman Matzen]]'s statue of Cleveland Mayor [[Tom L. Johnson]].]] Known as the "Sixth City" due to its position as the sixth largest U.S. city at the time, Cleveland counted major [[Progressive Era]] politicians among its leaders, most prominently the [[Populism|populist]] Mayor [[Tom L. Johnson]], who was responsible for the development of the Cleveland Mall Plan.{{Cite news|title= Cleveland Court Winner: Sixth City Gets Permanent Possession of Inter-Lake Trophy|date=August 3, 1919|url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/08/03/97111037.pdf |work=[[The New York Times]]| accessdate=July 6, 2010}}{{cite news| date= October 11, 1937|title= Ohio: Sixth City| url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,770907,00.html |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time.com]]| accessdate=July 5, 2010}}{{cite web |title=Johnson, Tom L.|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/j/johnson-tom-l |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= February 2019 }} The era of the [[City Beautiful movement]] in Cleveland architecture, this period also saw wealthy patrons support the establishment of the city's major cultural institutions. The most prominent among them were the [[Cleveland Museum of Art]], which opened in 1916, and the [[Cleveland Orchestra]], established in 1918.{{cite web |title=Museum History|url= http://www.clevelandart.org/about/about-the-museum/history-and-mission |publisher= Cleveland Museum of Art |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= October 5, 2012 }}{{cite book|title=Second to None: The Cleveland Orchestra Story|last=Rosenberg|first=Donald|date=2000|publisher=Gray & Company|isbn=9781886228245|location=Cleveland|pages=43–44}} Cleveland's economic growth and industrial jobs attracted large waves of [[Immigration to the United States|immigrants]] from [[Southern Europe|Southern]] and [[Eastern Europe]] as well as [[History of Ireland (1801–1923)|Ireland]].{{cite web |title=Immigration and Migration|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/i/immigration-and-migration |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= February 25, 2019 }} African American migrants from the rural [[Southern United States|South]] also arrived in Cleveland (among other Northeastern and Midwestern cities) as part of the [[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]] for jobs, constitutional rights, and relief from [[Jim Crow laws|racial discrimination]].{{cite web |title=African Americans|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/a/african-americans |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= July 15, 2019 }} By 1920, the year in which the [[Cleveland Indians]] won their [[1920 World Series|first World Series championship]], Cleveland had grown into a densely-populated metropolis of 796,841 with a foreign-born population of 30%, making it the fifth largest city in the nation.{{cite web |url=https://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0027/twps0027.html|title=Population of the 100 Largest Cities and Other Urban Places in the United States: 1790 to 1990|last=Gibson|first=Campbell|publisher=[[United States Census Bureau|U.S. Census Bureau]]|date=June 1998|accessdate=October 20, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Salling|first=Mark|last2=Cyran|first2=Ellen|title=Foreign-Born Population in Selected Ohio Cities, 1870 to 2000: A Brief Descriptive Report|url= https://engagedscholarship.csuohio.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1357&context=urban_facpub|publisher=[[Cleveland State University]]|date=January 1, 2006|accessdate= July 2, 2019}} At this time, Cleveland saw the rise of radical labor movements in response to the conditions of the largely immigrant and migrant workers. In 1919, the city attracted national attention amid the [[First Red Scare]] for the [[May Day riots of 1919|Cleveland May Day Riots]], in which [[socialism|socialist]] demonstrators clashed with anti-socialists.{{cite web |title=May Day Riots|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/m/may-day-riots |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= May 19, 2019 }}{{cite web | title =May Day Riot | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/28 | accessdate =July 22, 2019}} Despite the immigration restrictions of [[Emergency Quota Act|1921]] and [[Immigration Act of 1924|1924]], the city's population continued to grow throughout the 1920s. [[Prohibition in the United States|Prohibition]] first took effect in Ohio in May 1919 (although it was not well-enforced in Cleveland), became law with the [[Volstead Act]] in 1920, and was eventually [[Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution|repealed]] nationally by [[United States Congress|Congress]] in 1933.{{cite web |title=Prohibition Amendment|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/p/prohibition-amendment |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= June 18, 2018 }} The ban on alcohol led to the rise of [[Speakeasy|speakeasies]] throughout the city and organized crime gangs, such as the [[Mayfield Road Mob]], who smuggled bootleg liquor across [[Lake Erie]] from [[Canada]] into Cleveland.{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Ralph|title=Murder in Cleveland: The Prohibition Toll. Chapter 3—Rise of the Rum Kings; the 'Bloody Corner|publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=December 28, 1933|pages=1, 5}} The [[Roaring Twenties]] also saw the establishment of Cleveland's [[Playhouse Square]] and the rise of the risqué Short Vincent entertainment district.{{cite web | title =Playhouse Square |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] | url =https://case.edu/ech/articles/p/playhouse-square | accessdate =July 15, 2019|date= May 31, 2019 }}{{cite web | title =Short Vincent |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] | url =https://case.edu/ech/articles/s/short-vincent | accessdate =July 15, 2019|date= May 22, 2018 }}{{cite web | title =Short Vincent | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/64 | accessdate =July 15, 2019}} The Bal-Masque balls of the [[avant-garde]] [[Kokoon Arts Club]] scandalized the city.{{cite web | title =Kokoon Arts Club |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] | url =https://case.edu/ech/articles/k/kokoon-arts-club | accessdate =August 9, 2019|date= May 22, 2018 }}{{cite web | title =The Kokoon Arts Klub | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/851 | accessdate =August 9, 2019}} [[Jazz]] came to prominence in Cleveland during this period.{{cite web|last=Theiss|first=Evelyn|title=In Cleveland's 'second downtown,' jazz once filled the air: Elegant Cleveland|url= https://www.cleveland.com/arts/2012/02/in_clevelands_second_downtown.html|publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=February 5, 2012|accessdate= August 1, 2019}}{{cite web | title =Jazz | url =https://case.edu/ech/articles/j/jazz |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate=June 14, 2019| date =June 29, 2018 }}{{cite book | author=Mosbrook, Joe |url=https://engagedscholarship.csuohio.edu/scholbks/135/ |title=Jazzed in Cleveland |journal=Scholarship Collection | year=2003 | location=Cleveland | publisher=Northeast Ohio Jazz Society | isbn= 978-1-936323-02-9 | accessdate=2019-06-14}} [[File:terminal-tower-construction.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Cleveland's iconic [[Terminal Tower]] under construction in 1927.]] In 1929, the city hosted the first of many [[National Air Races]].{{cite web | title =Cleveland National Air Races | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/151 | accessdate =July 15, 2019}} Construction of the [[Terminal Tower]] [[skyscraper]] commenced in 1926 and, by the time it was dedicated in 1930, Cleveland had a population of over 900,000.{{cite book |author1=Toman, James |author2=Cook, Daniel |title=Cleveland's Towering Treasure |year=2005 |chapter=The Tower |page=76 |publisher=Cleveland Landmarks Press |location=Cleveleand, Ohio |isbn=0-936760-20-6}} The era of the [[flapper]] also marked the beginning of the golden age in Downtown Cleveland retail, centered on major department stores [[Higbee's]], Bailey's, the [[May Company Ohio|May Company]], [[William Taylor & Son|Taylor's]], [[Halle Brothers Co.|Halle's]], and [[Sterling-Lindner Co.|Sterling Lindner Davis]], which collectively represented one of the largest and most [[fashion]]able shopping districts in the country, often compared to New York's [[Fifth Avenue]].{{cite web |url=http://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/23#.Vd5BjZed6jg |title=Downtown Department Stores |accessdate=July 15, 2019|work=Cleveland Historical}} Cleveland was hit hard by the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]] and the subsequent [[Great Depression]]. A center of [[Labor unions in the United States|union activity]], the city was aided by major federal works projects sponsored by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]'s [[New Deal]].{{cite book|title=Cleveland: A Concise History, 1796–1996|last=Miller|first=Carol Poh|last2=Wheeler|first2=Robert A.|edition=2nd|date=1997|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=9780253211477|location=Bloomington|pages=136–139}} In commemoration of the centennial of Cleveland's incorporation as a city, the [[Great Lakes Exposition]] debuted in June 1936 at the city's [[North Coast Harbor]], along the Lake Erie shore north of downtown.{{cite book | author=Porter, Philip |chapter-url=http://www.clevelandmemory.org/SpecColl/porter/Chapt06.html |title=Cleveland: Confused City on a Seesaw | chapter=Chapter 6 | pages=106–107 | year=1976 | location=Columbus, Ohio | publisher=Ohio State University Press | isbn= 9780814202647 | accessdate= July 22, 2009 }} Conceived by Cleveland's business leaders as a way to revitalize the city during the Depression, it drew four million visitors in its first season, and seven million by the end of its second and final season in September 1937.{{cite web | url=https://case.edu/ech/articles/g/great-lakes-exposition | title=Great Lakes Exposition |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] | accessdate=July 15, 2019| date=March 21, 2019 }} On December 7, 1941, [[Empire of Japan|Imperial Japan]] [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|attacked Pearl Harbor]] and [[Japanese declaration of war on the United States and the British Empire|declared war]] on the United States. One of the victims of the attack was a Cleveland native, Rear Admiral [[Isaac C. Kidd]].{{cite web |title=World War II|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/w/world-war-ii |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= May 22, 2018 }} The attack signaled America's entry into [[World War II]]. A major hub of the "[[Arsenal of Democracy]]", Cleveland under Mayor [[Frank Lausche]] contributed massively to the [[United States home front during World War II|U.S. war effort]] as the fifth largest manufacturing center in the nation. During his tenure, Lausche also oversaw the establishment of the Cleveland Transit System, the predecessor to the [[Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority]].{{cite web |title=Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority|url=https://case.edu/ech/articles/g/greater-cleveland-regional-transit-authority|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 22, 2019|date=May 11, 2018}} ===Late 20th and early 21st centuries=== After the war, Cleveland initially experienced an economic boom, and businesses declared the city to be the "best location in the nation."{{cite book |title=Cleveland: Confused City on a Seesaw |first=Philip W. |last=Porter |year=1976 |chapter=Chapter Nine: Erieview, the Big Mistake: 1953–1962 |chapterurl=http://clevelandmemory.org/SpecColl/porter/Chapt09.html#p180 |isbn=9780814202647 |page=180 |publisher=[[Ohio State University Press]] |location=Columbus, Ohio |accessdate=July 22, 2009 }} Transcription at ''The Cleveland Memory Project'' website.{{cite web |title=Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co.|url=https://case.edu/ech/articles/c/cleveland-electric-illuminating-co|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 22, 2019|date=April 4, 2019}} In 1949, the city was named an [[All-America City Award|All-America City]] for the first time and, in 1950, its population reached 914,808.{{cite web |url=http://www.ncl.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=130&Itemid=186 |title=AAC Winners by State and City |publisher=[[National Civic League]] |accessdate=December 11, 2010}} In sports, the Indians won the [[1948 World Series]], the hockey team, the [[Cleveland Barons (1937–73)|Barons]], became champions of the American Hockey League, and the [[Cleveland Browns|Browns]] dominated professional [[National Football League|football]] in the 1950s. As a result, along with track and boxing champions produced, Cleveland was declared the "City of Champions" in sports at this time. The 1950s also saw the rising popularity of a new music genre that local [[WKNR|WJW (AM)]] disc jockey [[Alan Freed]] dubbed "[[rock and roll]]."{{cite web|url=https://case.edu/ech/articles/f/freed-alan |title=Freed, Alan |encyclopedia=The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate=June 22, 2010 }} [[File:Downtown Cleveland, Ohio, in winter, from the air, 12-1937 - NARA - 512842.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.3|The [[Cuyahoga River]] winds through [[the Flats]] in a December 1937 aerial view of [[Downtown Cleveland]].]] However, by the 1960s, Cleveland's economy began to slow down, and residents increasingly sought new housing in the suburbs, reflecting the national trends of suburban growth following federally subsidized highways.{{cite web |title=Suburbs |url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/s/suburbs |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= January 20, 2013}} Industrial restructuring, particularly in the railroad and steel industries, resulted in the loss of numerous jobs in Cleveland and the region, and the city suffered economically. The [[burning of the Cuyahoga River]] in June 1969 brought national attention to the issue of [[Pollution#Urban pollution|industrial pollution]] in Cleveland and served as a catalyst for the [[Environmental movement in the United States|American environmental movement]].{{cite web|last=Johnston|first=Laura|title=Cuyahoga named River of the Year|url=https://www.cleveland.com/news/2019/04/cuyahoga-named-river-of-the-year.html|publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=April 16, 2019|accessdate= July 10, 2019}} [[Housing discrimination in the United States|Housing discrimination]] and [[redlining]] against African Americans led to racial unrest in Cleveland and numerous other Northern U.S. cities.{{cite book|title=The Color of Law: A Forgotten History of How Our Government Segregated America|last=Rothstein|first=Richard|date=2017|publisher=Liveright (W. W. Norton & Company)|isbn=9781631492853|location=New York|page=14}}{{cite web|last=Eddings|first=Amy|title=Divided by Design: Tracking Neighborhood Racial Segregation in Cleveland|url=https://www.ideastream.org/news/divided-by-design-tracking-neighborhood-racial-segregation-in-cleveland|publisher=[[WVIZ]]|date=November 14, 2017|accessdate= July 3, 2019}} In Cleveland, the [[Hough riots]] erupted from July 18 to 23, 1966 and the [[Glenville Shootout]] took place from July 23 to 25, 1968. In November 1967, Cleveland became the first major American city to elect an African American mayor, [[Carl Stokes|Carl B. Stokes]], who served from 1968 to 1971.{{cite book|title=Promises of Power: A Political Autobiography|url=https://archive.org/details/promisesofpowerp00stok/page/42|last=Stokes|first=Carl B.|authorlink=Carl Stokes|date=1973|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9780671216023|location=New York|page=[https://archive.org/details/promisesofpowerp00stok/page/42 42]}} In December 1978, during the turbulent tenure of [[Dennis Kucinich]] as mayor, Cleveland became the first major American city since the Great Depression to enter into a [[default (finance)|financial default]] on federal loans.{{cite web |title=Mayoral Administration of Dennis J. Kucinich|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/m/mayoral-administration-dennis-j-kucinich|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 15, 2019|date= May 12, 2018}} By the beginning of the 1980s, several factors, including changes in international [[free trade]] policies, inflation, and the [[Savings and loan crisis|Savings and Loans Crisis]], contributed to [[Early 1980s recession|the recession]] that severely affected cities like Cleveland.{{cite web|title=The Banking Crises of the 1980s and Early 1990s: Summary and Implications|url=http://www.fdic.gov/bank/historical/history/3_85.pdf|work=Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation|accessdate=January 11, 2013}} While unemployment during the period peaked in 1983, Cleveland's rate of 13.8% was higher than the national average due to the closure of several steel production centers.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/07/business/republic-steel-to-close-mill.html | work=The New York Times | title=Republic Steel To Close Mill | date=August 7, 1982}}{{cite web|author=Jon Fobes/The Plain Dealer |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/openers/2009/02/unemployment_hits_nearly_every.html |title=Unemployment hits nearly every area in Ohio, analysis of new claims finds |publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]] |date=February 8, 2009 |accessdate=August 24, 2012}}{{cite web |title=Fisher Body Division of General Motors Corp.|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/f/fisher-body-division-general-motors-corp |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate=August 24, 2012}} The city began a gradual economic recovery under mayor [[George Voinovich|George V. Voinovich]] in the 1980s. The downtown area saw the construction of the [[Key Tower]] and [[200 Public Square]] skyscrapers, as well as the development of the [[Gateway Sports and Entertainment Complex]]—consisting of [[Progressive Field]] and [[Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse]]—and the North Coast Harbor, including the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]], [[FirstEnergy Stadium]], and the [[Great Lakes Science Center]].{{cite web |title=Mayoral Administration of George V. Voinovich|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/m/mayoral-administration-george-v-voinovich|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= August 3, 2019|date= February 21, 2019}} The city emerged from default in 1987. By the turn of the 21st century, Cleveland succeeded in developing a more diversified economy and gained a national reputation as a center for healthcare and the arts. Additionally, it has become a national leader in environmental protection, with its successful cleanup of the Cuyahoga River.{{cite web|last=Maag|first=Christopher|title=From the Ashes of '69, Cleveland's Cuyahoga River Is Reborn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/21/us/21river.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 20, 2009|accessdate= July 25, 2019}} The city's downtown has experienced dramatic economic and population growth since 2010.{{cite web|last=Exner|first=Rich|title=How downtown Cleveland is changing: by the numbers|url=https://www.cleveland.com/datacentral/2016/05/how_downtown_cleveland_is_chan.html|publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=May 13, 2016|accessdate= July 10, 2019}} In 2018, the population of Cleveland began to flatten after decades of decline.{{cite web|last=Exner|first=Rich|title=Cleveland's population flattens near 385,000 after decades of big losses, new census estimates say|url=https://expo.cleveland.com/news/g66l-2019/05/d1695a54c89135/clevelands-population-flattens-near-385000-after-decades-of-big-losses-new-census-estimates-say.html|publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=May 23, 2019|accessdate= July 15, 2019}} However, challenges still remain for the city, with economic development of neighborhoods, improvement of [[Cleveland Metropolitan School District|city schools]], and continued encouragement of new immigration to Cleveland being top municipal priorities.{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Frank G.|authorlink=Frank G. Jackson|url=http://www.cleveland-oh.gov/sites/default/files/forms_publications/HighlightsStateCity%20Address.pdf|title=2016 State of the City Address|publisher=City of Cleveland|accessdate=August 9, 2019}}{{cite web|last=Exner|first=Rich|title=Among counties, Cuyahoga near top in Midwest for attracting immigrants|url=https://www.cleveland.com/datacentral/2018/04/among_counties_cuyahoga_near_t.html|publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=April 2, 2018|accessdate= July 8, 2019}} Despite such challenges, Cleveland has become increasingly recognized by national media as a city on the upswing.{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Peter Lane|title=Why Cleveland Is America's Hottest City Right Now|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/petertaylor/2016/10/27/why-cleveland-is-americas-hottest-city-right-now/#2addf5686488|work=[[Forbes]]|date=October 27, 2016|accessdate= July 15, 2019}} This trend has been accompanied by major victories in sports, most prominently the victory of the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] in the [[2016 NBA Finals]], the first major professional sports championship won by a Cleveland team since [[Cleveland sports curse|1964]].{{cite news|last=McCauley|first=Janie|title=James and Cavaliers win thrilling NBA Finals Game 7, 93–89|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20160619/CLEGSW/gameinfo.html?ls=iref:nbahpt11a|publisher=National Basketball Association|date=June 19, 2016|accessdate=June 20, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814231002/http://www.nba.com/games/20160619/CLEGSW/gameinfo.html?ls=iref:nbahpt11a|archive-date=August 14, 2017|url-status=dead}} ==Geography== [[File:ISS-34 Night view of Cleveland, Ohio.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|[[NASA]] satellite photograph of Cleveland at night.]] According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|82.47|sqmi|km2|2}}, of which {{convert|77.70|sqmi|km2|2}} is land and {{convert|4.77|sqmi|km2|2}} is water.{{cite web|title=US Gazetteer files 2010 |url=http://www2.census.gov/geo/docs/maps-data/data/gazetteer/2010_place_list_39.txt |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]] |accessdate=June 6, 2016}} The shore of [[Lake Erie]] is {{convert|569|ft|m}} above [[above mean sea level|sea level]]; however, the city lies on a series of irregular bluffs lying roughly parallel to the lake. In Cleveland these bluffs are cut principally by the [[Cuyahoga River]], Big Creek, and [[Euclid Creek]]. The land rises quickly from the lake shores elevation of 569 feet. [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]], less than {{Convert|1|mi|km|spell=in}} inland, sits at an elevation of {{convert|650|ft|m|0}}, and Hopkins Airport, {{convert|5|mi|km|0}} inland from the lake, is at an elevation of {{convert|791|ft|m|0}}.{{cite web| url = http://www.airnav.com/airport/KCLE| publisher = AirNav| title = Cleveland-Hopkins International Airport| accessdate = May 9, 2007}} Cleveland borders several [[Inner suburb|inner-ring]] and [[streetcar suburbs|streetcar]] [[suburb]]s. To the west, it borders [[Lakewood, Ohio|Lakewood]], [[Rocky River, Ohio|Rocky River]], and [[Fairview Park, Ohio|Fairview Park]], and to the east, it borders [[Shaker Heights, Ohio|Shaker Heights]], [[Cleveland Heights, Ohio|Cleveland Heights]], [[South Euclid, Ohio|South Euclid]], and [[East Cleveland, Ohio|East Cleveland]]. To the southwest, it borders [[Linndale, Ohio|Linndale]], [[Brooklyn, Ohio|Brooklyn]], [[Parma, Ohio|Parma]], and [[Brook Park, Ohio|Brook Park]]. The city also borders [[Newburgh Heights, Ohio|Newburgh Heights]], [[Cuyahoga Heights, Ohio|Cuyahoga Heights]], and [[Brooklyn Heights, Ohio|Brooklyn Heights]] to the south, and [[Warrensville Heights, Ohio|Warrensville Heights]], [[Maple Heights, Ohio|Maple Heights]], and [[Garfield Heights, Ohio|Garfield Heights]] to the southeast. To the northeast, along the shore of Lake Erie, Cleveland borders [[Bratenahl, Ohio|Bratenahl]] and [[Euclid, Ohio|Euclid]]. ===Cityscapes=== {{Wide image|Public Square 1912.jpg|1500px|align-cap=center|Panorama of [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]] in 1912.|alt=Panorama of Cleveland's Public Square in 1912.}} {{Wide image|Downtown panorama.jpg|1500px|align-cap=center|Panorama of [[Downtown Cleveland]] from the [[East Ohio Building]].}} {{Wide image|Cleveland Skyline Aug 2006.JPG|1500px|align-cap=center|Skyline of Cleveland from [[Lake Erie]] in 2006, with the [[Key Tower]], the [[200 Public Square]], and the [[Terminal Tower]] at the center.}} ===Architecture=== {{See also|List of tallest buildings in Cleveland|National Register of Historic Places listings in Cleveland}} [[File:Cleveland Skyline (26381354620).jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|Terminal Tower and [[Euclid Avenue (Cleveland)|Euclid Avenue]].]] Cleveland's downtown architecture is diverse. Many of the city's government and civic buildings, including City Hall, the [[Cuyahoga County Courthouse]], the [[Cleveland Public Library]], and [[Public Auditorium]], are clustered around the open [[The Mall (Cleveland)|Cleveland Mall]] and share a common [[neoclassical architecture]]. Built in the early 20th century, they are the result of the 1903 Group Plan. They constitute one of the most complete examples of [[City Beautiful movement|City Beautiful]] design in the United States.{{cite book |last=Lawrence |first=Michael |title=Make No Little Plans |year=1980 |pages=20–25 |publisher=[[Western Reserve Historical Society]] |location=Cleveland |isbn=0-911704-24-8}}{{cite web |title=Mall|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/m/mall|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= August 21, 2019|date= May 22, 2018}} The [[Terminal Tower]], dedicated in 1930, was the tallest building in North America outside New York City until 1964 and the tallest in the city until 1991. It is a prototypical [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] [[skyscraper]]. The two newer skyscrapers on Public Square, [[Key Tower]] (currently the tallest building in Ohio) and the [[200 Public Square]], combine elements of [[Art Deco]] architecture with [[postmodern architecture|postmodern]] designs. Cleveland's architectural treasures also include the [[Cleveland Trust Company Building]], completed in 1907 and renovated in 2015 as a downtown [[Heinen's Fine Foods|Heinen's]] [[supermarket]], and the [[Cleveland Arcade]] (sometimes called the Old Arcade), a five-story [[arcade (architecture)|arcade]] built in 1890 and renovated in 2001 as a [[Hyatt]] Regency Hotel.{{cite web|last=Toledo|first=Charlotte Nicole|last2=Roy|first2=Chris|title =Cleveland Trust Company Building| work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/761 | accessdate =August 21, 2019}}{{cite web |title=The History of Our Cleveland Landmark|url=https://www.theclevelandarcade.com/history-of-the-arcade.htm|publisher=The Arcade|accessdate=August 8, 2019}}{{cite web|last=Raponi|first=Richard|last2=Rotman|first2=Michael|title =The Arcade| work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/24 | accessdate =August 8, 2019}} Running east from Public Square through University Circle is [[Euclid Avenue (Cleveland)|Euclid Avenue]], which was known for its prestige and elegance as a residential street. In the late 1880s, writer [[Bayard Taylor]] described it as "the most beautiful street in the world".{{cite book |last=Upton |first=Harriet Taylor |title=History of the Western Reserve |url=https://archive.org/details/historywesternr01cutlgoog |publisher= The Lewis Publishing Company |year=1910 |page=507}} Known as "Millionaires' Row", Euclid Avenue was world-renowned as the home of such major figures as [[John D. Rockefeller]], [[Mark Hanna]], and [[John Hay]].{{cite book |last=Cigliano |first=Jan |title=Showplace of America |publisher=Kent State University Press |year=1991 |isbn=0-87338-445-8}}{{cite web|last=Rose|first=Danielle|title =Millionaire's Row | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/10 | accessdate =August 8, 2019}}{{cite web |title=Euclid Ave.|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/e/euclid-ave |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= August 8, 2019|date= July 15, 2019 }} Cleveland's landmark [[ecclesiastical architecture]] includes the historic [[Old Stone Church (Cleveland)|Old Stone Church]] in downtown Cleveland and the [[onion dome]]d [[St. Theodosius Russian Orthodox Cathedral]] in [[Tremont, Cleveland|Tremont]], along with myriad ethnically inspired Roman Catholic churches.{{cite web |url=http://www.clevelandmemory.org/sacredlandmarks/ |title=Cleveland Sacred Landmarks |publisher=[[Cleveland State University]] |accessdate=January 5, 2008}}{{cite web|last=Raponi|first=Richard|title =Old Stone Church | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/165 | accessdate =August 8, 2019}}{{cite web|last=Rotman|first=Michael|last2=Dubelko|first2=Jim|title =St. Theodosius Cathedral | work =Cleveland Historical | url =https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/92 | accessdate =August 8, 2019}}{{cite web | title =St. Theodosius Russian Orthodox Cathedral |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] | url =https://case.edu/ech/articles/s/st-theodosius-russian-orthodox-cathedral | accessdate =August 8, 2019|date= July 30, 2019 }} ===Parks and nature=== {{See also|Cleveland Metroparks|Cleveland Public Parks District}} [[File:Cleveland Skyline (34826840941).jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|Downtown Cleveland from Edgewater Park.]] Known locally as the "Emerald Necklace", the [[Frederick Law Olmsted|Olmsted]]-inspired Cleveland Metroparks encircle Cleveland and Cuyahoga County. The city proper is home to the Metroparks' Brookside and Lakefront Reservations, as well as significant parts of the Rocky River, Washington, and Euclid Creek Reservations. The Lakefront Reservation, which provides public access to Lake Erie, consists of four parks: Edgewater Park, [[Whiskey Island (Cleveland)|Whiskey Island–Wendy Park]], East 55th Street Marina, and [[Gordon Park, Cleveland|Gordon Park]].{{cite web | title =Lakefront Reservation| publisher=Cleveland Metroparks | url =https://www.clevelandmetroparks.com/parks/visit/parks/lakefront-reservation| accessdate =August 3, 2019}} Three more parks fall under the jurisdiction of the Euclid Creek Reservation: Euclid Beach, Villa Angela, and Wildwood Marina.{{cite web | title =Euclid Creek Reservation| publisher=Cleveland Metroparks | url =https://www.clevelandmetroparks.com/parks/visit/parks/euclid-creek-reservation| accessdate =August 3, 2019}} Bike and hiking trails in the [[Brecksville Reservation|Brecksville]] and Bedford Reservations, along with Garfield Park further north, provide access to trails in the Cuyahoga Valley National Park. The extensive system of trails within [[Cuyahoga Valley National Park]] extends south into [[Summit County, Ohio|Summit County]], offering access to [[Summit Metro Parks]] as well. Also included in the system is the renowned [[Cleveland Metroparks Zoo]], established in 1882. Located in Big Creek valley, the zoo has one of the largest collection of [[primate]]s in North America.{{cite web | title =Cleveland Metroparks Zoo| publisher=Destination Cleveland | url =https://www.thisiscleveland.com/things-to-do/major-attractions/cleveland-metroparks-zoo| accessdate =August 3, 2019}} The Cleveland Metroparks provides ample opportunity for outdoor recreational activities. Hiking and biking trails, including single track mountain bike trails, wind extensively throughout the parks.{{Cite web|url=https://www.clevelandmetroparks.com/parks/visit/activities/event-activity-types/mountain-biking|title=Cleveland Metroparks - Mountain Biking|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}} Rock climbing is available at Whipp’s Ledges at the Hinckley Reservation.{{Cite web|url=https://www.clevelandmetroparks.com/parks/recreation/contact-our-recreation-staff/rock-climbing-permit|title=Cleveland Metroparks - Rock Climbing|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}} During the summer months, kayakers, paddle boarders, and rowing and sailing crews can be seen on the Cuyahoga River and Lake Erie. In the winter months, downhill skiing, snowboarding, and tubing are available not far from downtown at the [[Boston Mills/Brandywine Ski Resort|Boston Mills, Brandywine]] and [[Alpine Valley Ski Area|Alpine Valley]] Ski resorts. In addition to the Metroparks, Cleveland Public Parks District oversees the city's neighborhood parks, the largest of which is the historic [[Rockefeller Park]], notable for its late 19th century landmark bridges, Rockefeller Park Greenhouse, and [[Cleveland Cultural Gardens]], which celebrate the city's ethnic diversity.{{cite web |title=Rockefeller Park|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/r/rockefeller-park|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= August 21, 2019}}{{cite web |title=Cleveland Cultural Gardens|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/c/cleveland-cultural-gardens|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= August 21, 2019}} Just outside of Rockefeller Park, the [[Cleveland Botanical Garden]] in University Circle, established in 1930, is the oldest civic garden center in the nation.{{cite web |title=Cleveland Botanical Garden|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/c/cleveland-botanical-garden|encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= August 3, 2019}} Located in the historic FirstEnergy Powerhouse in the [[The Flats|Flats]], the [[Greater Cleveland Aquarium]] is the only independent, free-standing aquarium in the state of Ohio.{{cite web|author=Thomas Ondrey |url=http://www.cleveland.com/travel/index.ssf/2012/05/underwater_wonders_among_the_n.html |title=Underwater wonders among the newcomers in Northeast Ohio |publisher=The Plain Dealer |date=May 19, 2012 |accessdate=August 24, 2012}} [[File:Illuminated West Side Market.jpg|upright=1.3|left|thumb|The historic Ohio City neighborhood at night.]] ===Neighborhoods=== [[Downtown Cleveland]] is centered on [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]] and includes a wide range of districts. It contains the traditional Financial District and Civic Center, as well as the [[Cleveland Theater District]], which is home to [[Playhouse Square Center]]. Downtown also historically included the lively Short Vincent entertainment district, which emerged in the 1920s and reached its height in the 1940s and 1950s. Today the former Short Vincent forms part of the Financial District. Mixed-use neighborhoods, such as the [[The Flats|Flats]] and the [[Warehouse District, Cleveland|Warehouse District]], are occupied by industrial and office buildings as well as restaurants and bars. The number of downtown housing units, in the form of [[condominium]]s, [[loft apartment|lofts]], and apartments, has been on the increase since 2000 and especially 2010. Recent developments include the revival of the Flats, the [[HealthLine|Euclid Corridor Project]], and the developments along East 4th Street.{{cite news |first=Steven |last=Litt |title=RTA's Euclid Avenue HealthLine is faring well in ridership, innovation |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/architecture/2009/11/rtas_euclid_avenue_healthline.html |publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]] |date=November 29, 2009 |accessdate=November 30, 2009 }}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/travel/Clevelands-Signs-of-Renewal.html|title=Cleveland's Signs of Renewal|last=Michener|first=Charles|date=April 2011|magazine=Smithsonian|accessdate=January 22, 2013}} [[File:Cleveland Annexation Map 4-Color Final.png|thumb|upright=1.2|Map of the territorial evolution of Cleveland.]] Clevelanders geographically define themselves in terms of whether they live on the east or west side of the [[Cuyahoga River]]. The East Side includes the neighborhoods of [[Buckeye–Shaker]], [[Central, Cleveland|Central]], [[Collinwood]], Corlett, Euclid–Green, [[Fairfax, Cleveland|Fairfax]], Forest Hills, [[Glenville, Cleveland|Glenville]], [[Goodrich–Kirtland Park]] (with [[Asiatown, Cleveland|Asiatown]]), [[Hough, Cleveland|Hough]], [[Kinsman, Cleveland|Kinsman]], [[Lee–Miles]], Mount Pleasant, [[Nottingham, Ohio|Nottingham]], [[St. Clair–Superior|St. Clair-Superior]], [[Union–Miles Park]], [[University Circle]] (with [[University Circle#Little Italy|Little Italy]]), and [[Woodland Hills, Cleveland|Woodland Hills]]. The West Side includes the neighborhoods of [[Brooklyn Centre]], [[Clark–Fulton]], [[Detroit–Shoreway]], Cudell, [[Edgewater, Cleveland|Edgewater]], [[Ohio City, Cleveland|Ohio City]], [[Tremont, Cleveland|Tremont]], [[Old Brooklyn]], [[Stockyards, Cleveland|Stockyards]], West Boulevard, and the four neighborhoods colloquially known as [[West Park, Cleveland|West Park]]: [[Kamm's Corners]], Jefferson, [[Bellaire–Puritas, Cleveland|Puritas–Longmead]], and Riverside. Three neighborhoods in the Cuyahoga Valley are sometimes referred to as the South Side: [[Industrial Valley]], [[Broadway–Slavic Village]], and Tremont. Several neighborhoods have begun to attract the return of the middle class that left the city for the suburbs in the 1960s and 1970s. These neighborhoods are on both the West Side (Ohio City, Tremont, Detroit-Shoreway, and Edgewater) and the East Side (Collinwood, Hough, Fairfax, and Little Italy). Much of the growth has been spurred on by attracting [[creative class]] members, which in turn is spurring new residential development.{{cite web |last=Kennedy |first=Maureen |last2=Leonard |first2=Paul |url=http://www.brookings.edu/es/urban/gentrification/gentrificationexsum.htm |title=Dealing with Neighborhood Change: A Primer on Gentrification and Policy Choices |accessdate=2006-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009155119/http://www.brookings.edu/es/urban/gentrification/gentrificationexsum.htm |archivedate=October 9, 2007 |publisher=[[Brookings Institution]] |date=April 2001}} A live-work [[zoning]] overlay for the city's near East Side has facilitated the transformation of old industrial buildings into loft spaces for artists.{{cite web |last=Gill |first=Michael |url=http://www.freetimes.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=471 |title=Can the Creative Class Save Cleveland? |accessdate=2006-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040918065510/http://www.freetimes.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=471 |archivedate=September 18, 2004 |work=[[Free Times]] |date=October 29, 2003}} ===Climate=== [[File:Downtown Cleveland - Cleveland Sunrise (47288342872).jpg|thumb|Cleveland and [[Lake Erie]] in winter.]] Typical of the Great Lakes region, Cleveland exhibits a [[continental climate]] with four distinct seasons, which lies in the [[humid continental]] ([[Köppen climate classification|Köppen]] ''Dfa''){{cite journal |last=Kottek |first=Marcus |last2=Greiser |first2=Jürgen |last3=Beck |first3=Christoph |last4=Rudolf |first4=Bruno |last5=Rubel |first5=Franz |display-authors=2 |title=World Map of Köppen – Geiger Climate Classification |date=June 2006 |journal=Meteorologische Zeitschrift |volume=15 |issue=3 |page=261 |doi=10.1127/0941-2948/2006/0130 }} zone. Summers are warm and humid while winters are cold and snowy. The Lake Erie shoreline is very close to due east–west from the mouth of the Cuyahoga west to [[Sandusky, Ohio|Sandusky]], but at the mouth of the Cuyahoga it turns sharply northeast. This feature is the principal contributor to the [[lake effect snow]] that is typical in Cleveland (especially on the city's East Side) from mid-November until the surface of Lake Erie freezes, usually in late January or early February. The lake effect also causes a relative differential in geographical snowfall totals across the city: while Hopkins Airport, on the city's far West Side, has only reached {{convert|100|in|cm|0}} of snowfall in a season three times since record-keeping for snow began in 1893,[http://www.erh.noaa.gov/cle/climate/cle/records/cletop10snow.html Cleveland Snowfalle (sic) Statistics.] [[National Weather Service]]. Retrieved on October 11, 2005. ===Ethnicity=== [[File:Feast of the Assumption in Little Italy Cleveland (36388057482).jpg|upright=1.2|thumb|[[Cleveland Feast of the Assumption Festival|Feast of the Assumption]] in Little Italy.]] In the 19th and early 20th centuries, Cleveland saw a massive influx of [[Immigration to the United States|immigrants]] from [[History of Ireland (1801–1923)|Ireland]], [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]], and the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]], [[German Empire|German]], [[Russian Empire|Russian]], and [[Ottoman Empire]]s, most of whom were attracted by manufacturing jobs. As a result, Cleveland and Cuyahoga County today have substantial communities of [[Irish Americans|Irish]] (especially in [[West Park, Cleveland|West Park]]), [[Italian Americans|Italians]] (especially in [[University Circle#Little Italy|Little Italy]] and around Mayfield Road), [[German Americans|Germans]], and several [[Central Europe|Central]]-[[Eastern Europe]]an ethnicities, including [[Czech American|Czechs]], [[Hungarian Ohioans|Hungarians]], [[Lithuanian American|Lithuanians]], [[Polish Americans|Poles]], [[Romanian American|Romanians]], [[Russian Americans|Russians]], [[Rusyn Americans|Rusyns]], [[Slovak American|Slovaks]], [[Ukrainian American|Ukrainians]], and ex-[[Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] groups, such as [[Slovene Americans|Slovenes]], [[Croatian American|Croats]], and [[Serbian American|Serbs]]. The presence of Hungarians within Cleveland proper was, at one time, so great that the city boasted the highest concentration of Hungarians in the world outside of [[Budapest]].{{cite web |title=Hungarians|url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/h/hungarians |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 8, 2019|date= May 11, 2018 }} Cleveland has a long-established [[Jews and Judaism in Greater Cleveland|Jewish community]], historically centered on the East Side neighborhoods of [[Glenville, Cleveland|Glenville]] and [[Kinsman, Cleveland|Kinsman]], but now mostly concentrated in East Side suburbs such as [[Beachwood, Ohio|Beachwood]], home to the [[Maltz Museum of Jewish Heritage]].{{cite web |title=Jews & Judaism |url= https://case.edu/ech/articles/j/jews-judaism |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher= [[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate= July 2, 2019|date= May 11, 2018 }} The availability of jobs also attracted African Americans from the South. Between 1920 and 1970, the black population of Cleveland, largely concentrated on the city's East Side, increased significantly as a result of the [[Great Migration (African American)|First]] and [[Second Great Migration (African American)|Second Great Migrations]].
